segments.text: Okay, Mr. Rogers, what was your job at the Austin American Statement?
Well, I had a lot of jobs over a period of time.
I was there from 1952 until 1968.
The last job that I had was managing editor, and in previous to that I had been an assistant city editor, I had been a copy editor, I had been a reporter, but most of my time was spent either as
as an assistant city editor or as management editor.
Could you describe Austin in the 1960s as far as the race situation and the general attitude?
Well, I think Austin was caught up in the changes that were going on like other places and in some ways it was a
a site of ferment.
And there are a couple of reasons for that.
One is that the Austin leadership and I think Austin attitudes traditionally were really rather on the conservative side.
And but there was at the same time a very strong
liberal element in the community, mostly associated with the University of Texas and especially with the University of Texas students.
Of course, there are also faculty there.
But I think there also was a determination on the part of the city's political leadership to see to it that the law was carried out in the best way possible.
So while certainly there were tensions in the town,
as far as the integration of lunch counters and restrooms and public facilities like hotels and theaters and things like that.
There also was a strong force in the town acting on behalf of integration.
And the political leadership saw to it that the police department
whatever their own personal biases might be, behaved in a fashion to protect the rights of people who were sitting in at lunch counters or conducting marches or things like that.
And so actually, I think there was a minimum of trouble, a lot less than there could have been and a lot less than there were in other places.
What was the attitude of the public towards the media?
Well, I think that
Just in a general way, I think that the American Statesman and the television station suffered the same fate that most local media do.
You know, most people don't really like their own, or say they don't like their own hometown newspapers, their own hometown TV.
The assumption is that somewhere else people are all doing a better job.
There are a good many people who

had negative feelings toward the newspaper because we didn't do this or we didn't do that but but in that regard i don't think there was anything special about that i think that was just the generalized kind of an attitude that particularly monopoly media suffer in any town and i don't think it's changed all that much i think it still goes on it's really tough to be honored in your own town if you're in the news business when did you notice
Important changes come in the 60s as far as race.
Oh, I have no way in the world of...
pinpointing that on our memory for dates and all that kind of thing.
But of course, Austin was pretty consistent with all of the things that were going on elsewhere in the country.
And particularly after, especially after Kennedy's assassination in 1963, things moved very fast.
They moved very fast in Austin than they did everywhere else.

And in some ways, I suppose, Austin felt particularly close to these changes in the sense that Lyndon Johnson, who was essentially a local man, was the prime mover behind the great Russian civil rights legislation that took place after the Kennedy assassination.
And so I think civil rights was a matter that was much on the local minds and
Mr. Johnson, of course, flew into Austin when he came to the White House on 3rd and Alice.
So I think there was an acute awareness of everything that was going on.
Certainly, we can mark lots of social change in this country from the Kennedy assassination.
It had been beginning before that, but that gave it that great impetus.
And then the events that followed that, which was suddenly the assassination of Robert Kennedy and Martin Luther King and everything, and the whole business, and the March on Washington and all that.
It was just, Austin was caught up in it like the whole nation.
Well, how was student unrest at the University of Texas?
Well, I can't...
Boy, that seems like 10 million years ago somehow.
There was student unrest, but I don't recall that it took any particularly insidious forms.
There were...
There were students who joined in demonstrations about everything that came along, but I don't recall that we had any really serious confrontations of any kind.
And there were times when there were rather volatile speakers like Rap Brown and others who came, and they came in and got out with minor.
I think the most obvious thing about the students at the University of Texas at that time was their apparent difference from the rest of the population.
The alternative lifestyle business was starting.
Everybody was trying to see how scroungy you could look, and there was long hair, and open smoking a pot, and all those kinds of things that so outraged the established

established them in those days and of course the University of Texas was the center of that and some really you know you would hardly even pay any attention to them now but at that time it was like watching a freak show out on Guadalupe when you walked by the University because you know we've not seen this kind of thing before and so I think maybe that was the most obvious thing that was going on.
Well on this students
How, was there any newspaper bias towards them?
One way or the other?
One way or the other.
I really can't, I can't recall that there was.
We had a, I'm sure that in some of the ways that we handled some stories in the beginning,
that we probably were careless about the use of the word like hippie and things like that.
But I don't think there was any deliberate attempt on the part of the newspaper either to put these people down or to unduly support whatever their attitudes might be and whatnot.
Lord knows my memory may be faulty,
I can't recall that there was any particular difficulty one way or the other.
It seems to me that we treated that like any other news phenomenon that was going on.
And unconsciously, we probably wrote in ways that were derogatory and whatnot, although I don't think it was a deliberate kind of thing.
I think it's kind of like the unconscious sexism that we still fall into just because we don't even think about it.
Was there any rioting in Austin?
No, not rioting in the sense that it happened anywhere else.
We didn't, you know, the town was never set on fire or the streets weren't blocked or anything like that.
Partly it was, largely I think it was because the police by and large did not make bad mistakes in handling these things.
For example, when there were demonstrations, parades, and things like that, the police chief kept his riot squads out of sight.
He didn't do the kinds of things that might have provoked things.
And they were pretty careful about being sure that people who were heckling the paraders and that sort of thing or were trying to cause trouble when blacks were sitting in at the lunch counter.
That seems impossible, I guess.
Only a few years ago.
you know, they saw to it that people were able to exercise their rights to parade and to demonstrate and sit in if they wanted to and all that sort of thing.
So I think it was managed pretty well, and there certainly was nothing that I recall that even approached a riot.
Certainly nothing like the kinds of things that went on in Detroit and places like that.
Well, how many demonstrations and sit-ins were there?
Good grief.
I have no idea.
You know, it was just
The most obvious thing in terms of sit-ins that I remember was that for a series of weekends, the NCAA or whoever they were were regularly conducting sit-ins at lunch counters like at Woolworth's.
in downtown down on the course at that time with the six in Congress.
And there were, of course, people who showed up to jeer and all that kind of thing, but the police kept it under control.
And so, by and large, I think it happened with a minimum of difficulty considering the total difficulty that was going on in the country at the time.
And how many demonstrations were there?
Gosh, I don't know.
It seemed like somebody was always showing up on the steps of the Capitol or having a parade down Congress Avenue or something.
But I suppose that one of the reasons my memory is sort of dim about these things is because they were almost routine and they weren't just really not that upsetting.
They were just routine.
In the newsroom, what kind of coverage?
We covered them.
We always covered those things.
We always had reporters out.
But we were there more like you conduct a death watch when a famous person was getting ready to die.
We were there in case anything happened, you know, as much as anything else.
And we reported on them, and we ran photographs, and we reported such incidents as there were and whatnot, but, you know, we just handled them like any other news story that was going on.
We neither... We neither...
fomented them or made a big deal out of them.
About the rise of the counterculture or the hippie and the race riots, how much was it discussed among journalists in the newsroom?
Hmm.
I suppose that it was discussed in the same terms that we discussed any other kind of news that was going on.
I don't think that we...
I don't recall people sitting around and philosophizing and saying, gosh, I was down on the street today and I believe the counterculture is rising.
You know, this, after all, was an evolutionary kind of a thing.
It happened rapidly, but still and all, it's not the kind of thing that...
And of course, our people were aware of what was going on.
And partly, it depended on what kind of a beat you were covering.
I'm sure that the business writers had one view of the thing, and the police writers had another view of the thing, and so on.
But I think, by and large, as far as our newsroom is concerned, that there was a considerable amount of tolerance for the kind of change that was going on, certainly among the working news people.
We were observers of the scene day by day, and I suppose because we were, in a sense, we may have been less inclined
to comment on it than maybe some other people.
I mean, as I recall now that's far away from it, whatever it was we said about it or thought about it was pretty generally in terms of coverage we were giving to it.
You know, just another day at the office for us, I think.
As far as the editorial policies and such that when there was no bias one way or the other.
That's a very difficult thing to recall.
I'm have no doubt, though I don't actually have a memory of it that we may have had editorial from time to time suggested that the street people were

clogging up things and ought to be controlled a little bit better out around the university and we may have had some funny things objecting to the way they dressed and we may have had some anti-narcotics editorials and things like that but as far as saying that you know taking any kind of a staunchly anti-counterculture stand and abhorring the state of it well we didn't do that and we certainly
were editorially convinced that racial integration was the right thing.
Wherever bias occurred in coverage and so on was unconscious personal bias and certainly was not an institutional bias.
At this time, also, Vietnam was going on.
What kind of coverage was given to Vietnam, say, before 1964?
Well, Vietnam coverage was we didn't have anybody in Vietnam from our own staff or from our own organization.
So what our coverage was the coverage that the Associated Press and the United Press International were giving to the war.
And we pretty regularly gave it a prominent position
quite often was a lead story, but that's true of any war, because copy editors, by and large, are lazy, and the war is always a safe thing to put on top.
And so our coverage reflected what was reflected in the coverage generally.
In the beginning, we covered it the way we had covered wars in the past.
We pretty much accepted that in terms of the coverage that we were getting,
It was us and them, and there was to be a winning side and a losing side, and we wanted to win.
The traditional view, we'd had a war, and our view and our coverage began to change as the nation's view and coverage began to change.
When it became apparent that the commanders in the field were lying about almost everything they could think of, and that

Politically, it was a hopeless mire that nobody really understood what the war was about, that there was a great deal of unnecessary cruelty among the sides, and then the meat line business and all that kind of thing.
So there was nothing really different in terms of our approaches or our attitudes or our coverage, I think, than there was generally nationally.
But in fact, we had very little control over that because we were merely
really using what was coming to us from the war and whatnot.

And we had the same kind of arguments among people in our staff that the people in the United States generally were having about whether we ought to stay or whether we ought to get out or whether we ought to bomb the gooks or, you know, the kind of thing that went on.
And there were some who, of course, felt that the war was immoral.
There were people who personally sympathized with the young men who were fleeing Canada and all that kind of thing.
There were others who felt the opposite.
As far as the coverage was concerned, we were virtually, we were really captives of the wire services because we certainly didn't have any resources there.
There have been some studies done of newspapers in Texas, and they found that
stories about American losses in Vietnam, at least in the earlier days, were played down and given a less prominent position than they were in, say, New York or the Washington Post.
Could be.
I'm really not familiar with the studies.
And if our newspaper reflected that,
It was totally accidental, and it was based simply on the choices of whoever happened to be working on those things.
I can assure you that there was no institutional policy which said, we're going to downplay our losses and upplay their losses.
Such a conversation simply never took place.
Nobody ever thought about it.
The judgments that were made in terms of the play on the stories were simply the judgments of whoever happened to be in the slot.
It's that simple.
Whether it turned out that statistically you could establish that kind of bias or not, I have no idea.
But if so, it was a mere happenstance.
When the war started becoming unpopular, how much of a stance did the newspaper take editorially?
I have no memory of it.
I'm sorry.
I simply do not recall.

back in the 1960s when things were changing were journalists attitudes change yeah i think journalists attitudes began to change i think that by and large among working journalists there was a greater tolerance for change i think there was a greater empathy with the counterculture people i think there was a greater sense of
of the wrongness of the Vietnam War.
And I think, in general, probably, the journalists I knew, at least, tended to be more what Lucille categorized as liberal in their attitudes, I suppose.
And I think, by and large, in their own personal attitudes, they were out a little bit ahead, maybe, of the public at large on those things.
Having said that, I haven't said anything very startling.
I think that's true almost universally.
I don't think that those newsroom attitudes, however, necessarily have any great impact on the content or the play of news, because I think this is countervailed by the fact
publishers, by and large, tend to have an opposite political and philosophical and social orientation.
So I think, you know, a few things kind of play against each other, and you wind up with a kind of a neutrality, I think, as far as play and everything.
It's hard for people on the outside to cope with, but, you know, I'd be
The President's personal attitudes as reporters are under a little bit better control, I think, than a lot of the public likes to believe.
In fact, you are able to set those things aside and keep overt bias.
You cannot keep unconscious bias out, no question about that.
But I think you do keep overt bias out on things like that.
So I think what I remember from the 60s was a difference that is a kind of a consistent difference between news people and perhaps a larger public turns their own personal attitudes.
Back to the demonstrations for a minute.
Were there any instances where there was threat of a demonstration and your newspaper was concerned about the way they

play the story and the effect that the coverage would give well the most obvious example that i recall was a situation in which at some time i don't remember the exact date or whatnot that a rumor began to circulate around among people like bankers and other business leaders in town that there was a great invasion of blacks coming into oscar and that
somehow that they were coming in from outside and they were getting ready to have this gigantic thing and that Austin now was going to be put into peril.
And there were among that group people who wanted us to publish warnings to the public about this thing.
Well, we were really loathe to do that kind of thing because
What you're dealing with there is just applying a spark to the tinderbox.
And so we wanted to be mighty sure before we did anything at all, and we were not about to publish warnings to people that the blacks are coming for crying out loud.
And so we did mount an investigation, and we discovered that indeed there was an unusually large number of out-of-town black people in Austin.
But we also discovered that they were all Baptists, and they were coming for a camp meeting that weekend.
And so what we did was nothing.
And we did nothing because to have done anything, even to have denied the river, very likely would have inflamed a situation that actually didn't exist, which we very easily could have created

in cooperation with these rumors that were going around among responsible citizens of the town and so that's an instance in which we made a deliberate editorial judgment not to do something in order to avoid blowing the lid off so i don't know if that answers your question or not but that's certainly one illustration and also i think that illustrates
the way in which we approached all those things.
We had an acute sense, I think, during all that period of our responsibility not to be the catalyst that tore the town apart and whatnot.
And we certainly tried.
We didn't want to be in the business
quote, news management.
We didn't want to be in the business of providing cover-ups, but we also didn't want to be in the business of spreading the gas.
